title: How to make notes of current affairs for UPSC - Quora
tags: Union Public Service Commission of India

response.answer_text: Hi, I am sharing my experience here wrt notes making. Please design your strategy as it suits you. Firstly, I did not make any notes from NCERT or standard books. I kept revising the books only. Even for my optional, no notes were made. I kept revising the overall content (no short notes). Current Affairs for Pre When it comes to current affairs, I did not make any notes for Preliminary exam. I only revised from the monthly current affairs compilations given by UPSC IAS EXAM PREPARATION - INSIGHTS ON INDIA HOMEPAGE - INSIGHTS during the initial stage. At a later stage, that website gave subjectwise (Economy, Polity, Environment etc) concise content for revision dedicated to pre. Since this content was picked from their current affairs portion itself, there was nothing new here but only repackaging of content (this was more concise), and hence no new effort needed. Current Affairs for Mains After Preliminary, I realised that revising one whole year current affairs from monthly compilation booklets (they can be quite lengthy…more than 100 pages sometimes) would prove very time consuming. Here, I started making current affairs notes, in soft copy, paper wise. I would try to write in short the gist of a given topic or copy paste some good question (from “Secure” initiative of UPSC IAS EXAM PREPARATION - INSIGHTS ON INDIA HOMEPAGE - INSIGHTS). Please note that I did not do it systematically; at times I would follow “Secure”, else copy from the current affairs/editorials of UPSC IAS EXAM PREPARATION - INSIGHTS ON INDIA HOMEPAGE - INSIGHTS and on other days, I would not make any additions to my notes from current affairs. All through this, I would often wonder that these notes would not be sufficient rather I will have to take time out to revise full one year current affairs. I tried but found that it was simply not possible to revise all of that and hence unwillingly stuck to my notes only while being fully aware that they were not exhaustive. So, Please note that it was not a methodical, well thought exercise at note making but somewhat haphazard. For your information, I would be attaching my notes here but please refer to them only to get an idea (they would be outdated/less relevant wrt upcoming mains examination). When it comes to revision, I revised my soft copy notes many times (4-5 times easily) before mains. For successive revisions, I did not read the entire document again but kept marking the stuff that I found difficult to retain (highlight the text in yellow on word doc) and hence time for subsequent revisions came down. My Excel Notes I had prepared some notes in Excel document which I had started at the time of pre and then kept updating it for Mains/Interview stage too. Basically, it contained one sheet on different organisations (SAARC, ASEAN etc), another on various reports (like ease of doing business) and others on some trivia.

Primary focus should be given to editorials, defence news, economy, constitutional amendments, Environment, Government bills and schemes, International affairs, social issues, court rulings, etc.Ignore: purely political news, celebrity related news, hyperlocal news, and most of the sports news.Make notes in your own words. Highlight, underline important keywords and add information from trusted sources like PIB, Yojana, and PRS.An aspirant is expected to note down the summary of important issues and articles. Maintain the very essence of the article, note down the theme, facts, reasons, benefits, implications, etc.The notes prepared for current affairs need to be crisp. As they say, “Less is always more in UPSC preparation”.For making notes, Byju’s video news analysis can be a good starting point to understand relevant issues pertaining to the UPSC exam.One needs to learn how to relatedynamic and static sources to get an in-depth understanding. When a judgment or ruling is noted down, a student also needs to understand its relevance to the syllabus by associating it with Polity, Economics or Geography.Make a habit of noting down social issues and challenges that our society is facing. An aspirant can quote the same in UPSC GS or Essay papers to substantiate their point. While noting this down, include all the facts, pros and cons and also note down any recent incidents related to that.There are many issues which can be asked in Prelims, multiple GS papers in Mains and even in the Interview. For e.g., news related to the linking of rivers, water conservation, water disputes. Keeping a check on these hot topics will give an aspirant a detailed understanding.Editorials are extremely important as they contain opinions and analysis on various subjects. Editorials can have biased opinions. But as a UPSC aspirant, it is expected of that person to identify points, both for the topic and against the topic. This helps in building one’s perspective which needs to be neutral.The note making can be digital or on paper but they need to be sorted as per the UPSC syllabus for quick revision and maximum impact.Don’t procrastinate when it comes to adding/appending notes as the particular news article may only be a short report on a complicated ongoing issue.Finally, revise, revise, revise!

UPSC aspirants most of the time have been found confused between reading from different sources and note making. Actually note making itself a time consuming, boring,and a tedious process where extra efforts and hard work is required,this makes the candidate sometimes demotivated and confused, because they are unable to reach at the conclusion, that whether the time and hard work which they are putting is in the right direction. However if you have prepared your notes well it will be very helpful during revision period and would be deciding factor in clearing the exam. Now how to make notes for current affairs- First Limit the sources from which you want to prepare notesSources may be Hindu, pib, or any other website, do not make notes from magazines, they are supplementaryMake 4 folders - GS1, GS2, GS3, GS4Make the notes according to upsc syllabusSuppose a news comes on Ind-USA relation, add simply in GS2, similar do this for each paperNow at the end of each month supplement your GS notes with any coachings’ current affairs booklet - vision, Vajiram etcAt the end of the year you would have only four folders to revise, this will help in prelims as well as in Mains exam and will make your task and life easyTry not repeat your notes and make them simple, crisp and in synopsis form

There is no hard and fast rule of notes making. Its always better and advisable to develop your own style of making notes. Now coming to your question, I am mentioning below some of the pointers you should keep in your mind while making the notes : Make concise notes, there is no need to write grammatically correct sentences, till you can understand it. Make it short and manageable enough to have a last moment revision.Always have a habit to leave margins and blank pages after your notes, so that if any new development happens in the field, you can append it later.Write only the things which you cannot memorize or feel is important, try to memorize as much as you can.Revise your notes frequently, preferably daily at the end of your day.Try to consolidate your notes, you can dedicate one register for each subject or the way which is comfortable to you.You can also make notes on A4 sheets and utilize them as flash cards during your revision.The list given above is just indicative and not comprehensive. There are many other ways in which you can enhance your note making, but what may work for one may not be comfortable with you. So focus on developing your own style of learning. Happy Learning !!

Thanks For A2A. Current affairs now a days are so much important for UPSC Civil Services Examination. If You Analyse this year paper, you will found that nearly 90 question was based on contemporary theme, so analyzing closely of current affairs is must to get selection in UPSC CSE Examination. So to make note one should follow either the Hindu Newspaper or Indian express. then follow PIB , sometimes Business-standard. Follow Rajya Sabha TV News And Several other programmes likewise for Lok Sabha TV. Programmes like security scan, Science monitor, expert Talk are so much relevant for current affairs. Consolidation and Analyzing this much fragmented information will be tedious task, will consume lot of time, retaining is also necessary. Alternative to this is you can follow a good Current Affairs Magazine. Following magazine will enable you to consolidate information at one place, help in revision. further it will reduce time given for current affairs. So that you can Study about other portion of syllabus with sufficient revisions. In my opinion Khan study Group (KSG’s) Current Connect is very good magazine. likewise vision IAS magazine is also good.

Current Affairs can be comprehensively covered by: Read Hindu/ Indian Express daily and build a comprehensive idea and knowledge of important topics. Newspapers are not for notes making as single newspaper cannot cover everything. Also the news/editorials on same topics may be widely distributed over month.Read 2 Current Affairs Magazine. Vision IAS monthly is good. And the other can be either Vajiram or Insight IAS daily. So that you don't miss any question in prelims or mains.I used to prepare a list of topics which were in news for the month and write answers on them at end of each month. This becos when u search them on internet articles from all the newspapers and magazines would appear. U cud read them and make answers directly on topic. This prepares a ready answer for mains.For “prelims” u cud make file for each section like polity, economy, defence ,tech and jot down only the facts from magazines.Thus u will have ur concise notes ready for revision for both prelims and Mains. All the Best…

This is what I am doing. Step 1 Taking 10 to 12 sheets of A4 pages and staple them together. Step 2 Make 6 to 7 copies like that Step 3 At the top of each copies write Certain headlines like GENERAL, TECHNOLOGY,IR, TRIBES, ENVIRONMENT,SPORTS,POLITY,ECONOMY etc like that. Step 4 Follow PIB,THE HINDU, magazines,other IAS related sites and update it daily under topic sheets with mentioning source. At the end of month you will get the best current notes . My Sample-       And those news in current which are imp from mains perspective need to be write in mains related copy.    It's from hindu article. Hope you got it All the best ✌️

Firstly, read The Hindu religiously with a rough copy in your hand.and,try to understand the newspaper. Whichever term is unknown for you ,note it down in rough copy and search it on Google.Don't make notes from newspaper, finish it by understanding it.In the evening,when IAS BABA ,or Insight On India updates their current affairs ,then make notes out of it.It will help you understand the content in more depth as they also add few more points .Revise it,and give a regular test on current affairs ,published by IAS BABA and Insight on India . It will help you to keep summarising.And,Don't forget to read the monthly magazines published by them.Revise them thrice and you will surely have a better command over current affairs.

Why you have to make notes, when there is already readymade notes are available in market. If you want to make notes then make notes for diagrams, flowchart,graph, pie chart etc ( i am attaching images for reference) for easy representation and quick revision. There are many type of notes available in market full notes, short notes, even micro notes are available in market. On basis of my my experiences I would suggest to follow.   Read newspaper daily and a quick revision of editorials.Take a good coaching’s monthly magazine and revise it two and three time and then make very short notes. Which can be attached with magazine.Convert words in form of diagram block diagram and flowchart etc.

I'll tell you what I do everyday. If you like it, you could also too! My morning starts with reading the newspaper - The Hindu. I spend about 45–60 minutes, not more. While reading, I jot down the important news in a diary. I skip the editorials. Next, I watch Learning Space’s editorial analysis on YouTube. Only after watching the video, I read the editorials. This makes me undertand the editorials better. I make notes of important articles OR print and highlight. In the evening, I watch Unacademy’s Daily Summary Analysis. If there's something I missed, I can now add it in my diary. Finally, to check whether I'm updated, I solve MCQs on Unacademy by Roman Saini. All this takes time, but then it's worth it keeping in mind that the UPSC exam is becoming current affairs-oriented. Good luck!

Read a newspaper like hindu or Indian express religiously. Make notes from it in the form of keywords so that during the time of revision it becomes easy to go through all the months. In addition to this,go through current connect available in the market. This will help you expand the horizons of your current knowledge and will help you focus more on events which are important for the examination. Solve full length current affairs test series by various institutions such as KSG, vision etc. They will help you supplement current affairs topics through their questions and explanations. You should flag their questions and answers which you find difficulty or you want to add it to your notes. Write important pointers, keywords in your notes and make it a condensed compilation.

I think these few points should help you The notes should be precise. You should make such notes that in the last week or month before the exam you can make a quick revision. Also if notes are short you are more likely to revise them.Learn more write less : Try to learn things instead of noting them down because maximum time you will just make the notes and never bother to read them.Use of technology : It doesn't matter if you make notes on laptop or paper, what matters is time. If you find any important article in newspaper or anywhere you should directly save its link or screenshot instead of writing the points on paper. Also soft copy notes are easy to handle.Revise again and again. It doesn't matter how your notes are because in the exam they are useful only if you have them in your mind.Make notes topicwise like environment, schemes, defence, women, Sc & St, international relations etc.Finally keep focused and believe in your self and believe me your notes are the best. :) All the best for the exam! Thanks for reading

For current Affairs, you must make notes from authentic sources like - ‘The Hindu & Indian Express Newspaper’, PIB, PRS, Govt. Websites & their annual reports, RSTV Videos, etc. Moreover, there is a trend wherein aspirants gives a lot of importance to Current affairs. But if we see Prelims paper, UPSC is asking such current affairs questions which aren’t mentioned in most of Current affairs magazines. So, read current affairs magazines of IAS Coaching Institutes only if you cant make notes from yourself. Few current affairs magazines which you can refer includes- Current connect of KSG India and Prelims & Mains 365 of Vision IAS. Hope this helps:)

take a thick spiral coy or you can use your A4 size blank sheet . divide it into sections like - International org. ; govt. schemes ; polity ; economics ; science & tech ; security ;Environment ; culture ; International issues ; mapping ; miscellaneous . And write in these section what news or materials you have collected from any sources . according to my prescription what i follow is ..vision IAS CF and ONLYIAS youtube discussion .

Hi, I follow the DNS videos which are uploaded in YouTube by Rau’s IAS Study Circle. The videos are properly explained by the faculty of the institute and you will be guided how to study and prepare motes for current affairs. For more details click on https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=rau%27s+dns+videos
open_you tube > search _prelim booster news discussion_and you will make a small short notes on each and every important topics In a diary or copy!! :)

reading of news papper daily the hindu…subscrip to ONLY ias youtubchannel it will help u in daily current affair and the hindu editorials…he upload daily…based news vedio… and read daily PIB … just note down important schemes… international relations and imp national news… avoid political based news..

Signup to Get latest currents affairs daily test with answer key & full explanation. Source:- Indian Express, The Hindu, Diplomat, Down to Earth, Livemint etc. Register on the Chronicle IAS it is completely free and also you can download free solved Previous year question paper.
